required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The European Robotic Spinal Instrumentation (EUROSPIN) Registry
clinical_study.official_title: The European Robotic Spinal Instrumentation (EUROSPIN) Registry: A European Prospective Multicenter Multinational Registry on Robot-guided Versus Navigated Versus Freehand Pedicle Screw Fixation

brief_summary.textblock: In a multinational prospective registry, preoperative, intraoperative, perioperative and follow-up data on patients receiving thoracolumbar pedicle screw placement for degenerative disease or infections or tumors will be collected. The three arms consist of robot-guided (RG), navigated (NV), or freehand (FH) screw insertion.

detailed_description.textblock:
Introduction A decade ago, minimally invasive surgery (MIS) was considered a promising development in spine surgery, yet the value of the pioneering technologies was questionable. With the growing number of experienced MIS surgeons, the influx of evidence in favour of MIS is rapidly increasing. This makes a compelling argument towards MIS offering distinct clinical benefits over open approaches in terms of blood loss, length of stay, rehabilitation, cost-effectiveness and perioperative patient comfort1. Due to the limited or inexistent line-of-sight in MIS procedures, surgeons need to rely on imaging, navigation, and guidance technologies to operate in a safe and efficient manner. Therefore, a plethora of new and ever improving navigational systems have been developed. These systems allow a consistent level of safety and accuracy, on par with results achieved by very experienced free hand surgeons, with a reasonably short learning curve2-4. Computer-based navigation systems were first introduced to spine surgery in 1995 and while they have been long established as standards in certain cranial procedures, they have not been similarly adopted in spine surgery.
Designed to overcome some of the limitations of navigation-based technologies, robot-guided surgery has become commercially available to surgeons worldwide, like SpineAssist® (Mazor Robotics Ltd. Caesarea, Israel) and the recently launched ROSA™ Spine (Zimmer-Biomet, Warsaw, Indiana, USA). These systems are rapidly challenging the gold standards. SpineAssist®, and its upgraded version, the Renaissance®, provides a stable drilling platform and restricts the surgeon's natural full range of motion to 2 degrees of freedom (up/down motion and yaw in the cannula). The system's guidance unit moves into the trajectory based on exact preoperative planning of pedicle screws, while accounting for changes in intervertebral relationships such as due to distraction, cage insertion or changes between the supine patient position in the preoperative CT and the prone patient on the operating table. Published evidence on robot-guided screw placement has demonstrated high levels of accuracy with most reports ranging around 98% of screws placed within the pedicle or with a cortical encroachment of less than 2 mm.4 Although the reliability and accuracy of robot-guided spine surgery have been established, the actual benefits for the patient in terms of clinical outcomes and revision surgeries remain unknown. We have recently conducted cohort studies that showed some evidence that robotic guidance lowers the rate of intraoperative screw revisions and implant related reoperations compared to free hand procedures, while achieving comparable clinical outcomes.5-7 We now want to assess these factors, among others, on a higher level of evidence. We aim to conduct a prospective, multicenter, multinational controlled trial comparing clinical and patient reported outcomes of robotic guided (RG) pedicle screw placement vs. navigated (NV) vs. free hand (FH) pedicle screw placement using pooled data from three centers.
Methods Overview The index variable will be the method of pedicle screw insertion. Patients will receive either robot-guided pedicle screw fixation (Mazor Robotics SpineAssist and Renaissance), navigated pedicle screw fixation (either CT-, O-Arm or Iso3DFL-based), or conventional freehand pedicle screw fixation.
Study Design This will be a prospective observational study with pooled data from 3 centers and 3 arms (RG, NV, FH). Data will be prospectively collected. In addition, a separate analysis will be performed with already prospectively collected data that is applicable to this protocol. An intermediate analysis will be performed after 75 patients have been enrolled in all 3 groups.
Sample Size Analysis
- Using the primary endpoint (overall rate of screw revisions (intraoperative screw revisions + revision surgery for screw malposition)) and previously published data from a review of the literature5, it was determined that, in order to detect an intergroup difference of 5%, 205 patients are required per group to achieve a power of 1-beta = 0.8 with a ChiSquare test at p = 0.05.
Patients Inclusion Criteria
- Informed consent
- Thoracolumbar pedicle screw placement
- Indication for surgery: Degenerative pathologies (stenosis, spondylolisthesis, degenerative disc disease, recurrent disc herniation), infections, tumors, fractures, trauma
- Age ≥ 18
Exclusion Criteria - Deformity surgery (>5 index levels)
Patients will be thoroughly informed about the techniques, risks and backgrounds of the pertaining procedure.
This is a prospective study. Analysis will occur on a per protocol basis. To provide optimal treatment quality, the procedures will be carried out surgeon-based: This means that surgeons who are most experienced in using robotic guidance will carry out all RG procedures and surgeons most experienced in using the free hand technique will carry out all FH procedures, etc.
Data Management Each participating center will maintain a proprietary database, with identical structure. The databases should be kept anonymous, with each center maintaining its own, separate key that links study-specific patient numbers to birthdate and name.
Twice yearly (1. December and 1. July), the anonymous databases will be sent to the principal investigator and stored safely.
Follow-Up Baseline data will be collected at the patients first visit. Perioperative data will also be entered. Patients will be followed up after 6 weeks, 1 year and 2 years at a follow-up visit or by use of mailed questionnaires.
Data Collection
Primary Endpoint:
- Overall rate of screw revisions (intraoperative screw revisions + revision surgery for screw malposition)
Secondary Endpoints:
Perioperative Data
The following data will be entered into the database perioperatively:
- Pedicle screw insertion method (RG vs NV vs FH)
- MIS or Open Surgery?
- Duration of Surgery (min.)
- Length of Stay (d.)
- Radiation Dose as DAP (cGy cm2)
- Estimated Blood Loss (ml)
- Need for blood transfusion
- Intraoperative Complications
- Postoperative Complications
- Intraoperative pedicle screw revisions
- Reoperations for pedicle screw malposition
Clinical and Patient Reported Outcome Measures
Baseline:
- Indication for surgery
- Index Level(s)
- Age
- Height
- Weight
- BMI
- History of pain (mo.)
- Prior surgery at the index level
- Highest level of education (elementary/highschool/higher education/(post-)doctoral)
- Type of work (employed/self-employed/housework/student/retired/unemployed)
The following variables will be assessed at baseline, and at 6 weeks, 12 months and 24 months follow up:
- Frequency of use of analgetics (daily/weekly/not regularly)
- Satisfaction with symptoms (satisfied/neutral/dissatisfied)
- Smoking status (active/ceased/never)
- Working status (able to work/unable to work)
- EQ-5D-3L8
- VAS back pain severity
- VAS leg pain severity
- Oswestry Disability Index9
In addition, only at follow-up visits:
- Return to work (weeks/not)
- Any reoperations
Statistics Categorical data are reported as numbers and percentages, and continuous data as mean ± standard deviation. Depending on the type of data, intergroup comparisons will be performed using ChiSquare tests, ANOVA or Kruskal-Wallis H tests, and subsequent independent t-tests or Mann-Whitney U tests with a Bonferroni-Holm correction for multiple testing. The Minimal Clinically Important Difference (MCID) will be defined as a ≥30 % improvement in the respective score.10 Longitudinal data will be assessed using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test. All analyses will be performed blinded to group assignment using version 3.4.2 of R.11 A two-tailed p < 0.05 was considered significant.

primary_outcome.description: Overall rate of screw revisions (intraoperative screw revisions + revision surgery for screw malposition)

secondary_outcome.description: Radiation Dose as DAP (Dose Area Product, cGy cm2)
Visual Analogue Scale of back pain severity
Visual Analogue Scale of leg pain severity
Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) for functional impairment

other_outcome.description: Frequency of use of analgetics (daily/weekly/not regularly)
Working status (able to work/unable to work)
Return to work (number of weeks/not yet)

arm_group.description: This arm will comprise all patients that receive transpedicular instrumentation by use of a robotic guidance system (SpineAssist or Renaissance, Mazor Robotics, Ltd., Caesarea, Israel or ROSA Spine, Medtech, Montpellier, France).
This arm will comprise all patients that receive transpedicular instrumentation by use of navigation (computer assistance using CT, O-arm or 3D-fluoroscopic imaging).
This arm will comprise all patients that receive transpedicular instrumentation by use of the conventional freehand technique.

study_pop.textblock: Patients receiving thoracolumbar transpedicular screw placement for degenerative pathologies (stenosis, spondylolisthesis, degenerative disc disease, recurrent disc herniation), infections, fractures, trauma, or tumors.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- Informed consent
- Thoracolumbar pedicle screw placement
- Indication for surgery: Degenerative pathologies (stenosis, spondylolisthesis, degenerative disc disease, recurrent disc herniation), infections, tumors, fractures, trauma
- Age ≥ 18
Exclusion Criteria
- Deformity surgery (>5 index levels)
